um uh trying out when I first got into SAS and it was just like nesting I I

on um to whatever's the most um immediate parent and you can also Nest
the parent selector inside of things so in this case if you're using like HML 5 boiler plate you know how it does those
like IE classes um that you can use the style things to override um you can keep
everything together by just writing hyph 6 Amper understand and it what's what it

so that can be pretty helpful if you're only maybe you're just overwriting one thing um rather than tacking it all at

output um one I guess less known thing that you can do is you can Nest
properties and so if you're writing a style for your borders and then maybe you're changing the color of the top and
turning off uh the left border um you don't have to write border over and over again you can just write border once and
then whatever comes um after The Hyphen can just be nested inside so that's um
not like a super useful thing but it can be helpful at
times so variables are what really really made me embrace SAS at first I was reluctant to use it I was one of
those designers that was like oh I handw write my CSS I don't need a CSS pre-processor and then I started using
variables and I realized I was really really wrong about that it's really awesome that I can just have one spot
where my colors and maybe um my type is
um like set at certain sizes and I want to use consistent sizing everywhere um variables give you
that um and then mixin and extend are things I I kind of took on after that um
the thing I really love about Mixon is you can pass things through them um like
arguments through them so maybe you have um like a consistent padding for your
boxes and so you just make this mix in so you make it really easy to get the proper spacing but then for a certain um
box you want to override that um this might not be an a a really good example
of that but um if you imagine like more um more detailed mixins that you might
be writing maybe you want to take on all the same things but like one or two things are different you can pass that
through with the parentheses and um override it so um that's particularly
helpful if you're using it for like border radiuses or box sh shadows and things like
that um so the problem with Mixon however is that block of code gets printed over and over again that's
actually one of the big problems I have with less and why I prefer SAS is every time you call upon a Mixon that's being
printed in your CSS again so the idea of extend uh was born from that uh problem
um so what SAS does is um lets you extend on a selector so in this case
like maybe you have um a div called message and it's like this nice fancy
message styling and then maybe you have another one that's called error and it looks almost like message but maybe the
background color is different or maybe it has a different icon um and uh the
older way we would probably do that is we might write um in our HTML message space error so we have two classes um so
the idea of extent is to find a way to not have to use two classes you can just use the one and so you can have alert
extend upon message and what that will do is instead of printing those styles
again it'll tack it on with a comma um so it shares those Styles um the other
thing to keep in mind is like every time you call upon message and it's going to tack it on to there so if you have a
message. alert now you're going to have a error. alert um but this is really
helpful in keeping your CSS a lot cleaner however the the problem with
that is like sometimes um people are making these um placeholder classes just
to be extended upon so like maybe you have a a class of clear fix you don't
actually ever use Clear fix in your HTML but you have it in your SAS so that you
can extend upon it every time you need it but now that class of clear fix is being output in your CSS so the idea of
placeholder selectors uh just recently came out in the new SAS version and these are really really
awesome um so instead of a class these are like silent classes and so instead
of a DOT you would use a a percentage sign so this is really awesome for grid
systems maybe you're using the popular 960 grid system and right now your CSS would output grid one grid two grid
three grid four maybe you're not using all of those um if you make them into silent classes um they're only going to
uh be extended upon they're never going to show up in your output and all the placeholder selectors you might have
widths for that aren't being used those won't ever get output either because they're not being used yet um so this is
like a huge huge win for for SAS if you're not using SAS you should be using
SAS this one I really like um especially for um design I like to design in the

I like to keep vendor stuff separate from my stuff I also like to keep my
layout images that are being brought in through CSS separate from my content images that are like you know embedded
in the page so that's I think that's a helpful thing to mention um but again
stay organized um one of the things I learned
when I first started writing SAS is that um nesting can really get you in trouble
um it's really cool but it also can mess you up and so um my general rule is try
not to Nest more than 3A deep if you're nesting more than 3A deep you're probably doing something wrong um I
think a lot of people that try out SAS like they love that it's like this whole indented thing and they can read where
everything is and so they kind of write it like the document um model but when you do that it's creating all those
really long selectors and not only is your CSS actually going to end up larger
than it should be it's also too specific and things aren't as modular and reusable as they should be um so like
not only do you want your code to be where you aren't repeating yourselves but you want your UI elements to be
reusable um and not have to create them over and over again so keep things as
less specific as possible um it makes your CSS more usable more maintainable
and cleaner so this was um an early version
of the style guide I was working on when I was at engine yard and started kind of
documenting like what all the different UI elements were and I found out that this um was way better than documenting
on like a Wiki or documenting on a PDF file I actually put the style guide on
the app itself as a page inside the app and so all the UI elements are rendering
from the exact same code that you're documenting and so if it's broken here then you know it's broken in your app
and so it's kind of awesome to do is because it becomes um like a Sandbox in a way where you can start building

acts as a form of QA in a way where you can make sure that all your elements are looking
right um the other awesome thing keeping in mind the whole like keep it current and useful keeping like if you're
